Description: Frontier Refining and Frontier El Dorado Refining agreed to pay civil penalties of $1.38 million and spend approximately $141 million in pollution control upgrades for alleged Clean Air Act violations at its refineries in Cheyenne, Wyo., and El Dorado, Kan.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that Frontier Refining has agreed to pay $153,000 in penalties to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act (CAA) and the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) at its Cheyenne, Wyo. refinery. The agreement resolves alleged violations of the risk management planning requirements of the CAA and Toxic Release Inventory reporting requirements under EPCRA.

Notes: Year is fiscal year. Date is closing date.

Description: In a Consent Agreement filed on May 27, 2010 the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Frontier Refining Inc., a petroleum facility in Cheyenne, Wyoming, resolved an enforcement action initiated in September 2009.

Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration
Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Company: Holly Frontier El Dorado Refining LLC

Description: Holly Refining & Marketing agreed to spend more than $17 million in new and upgraded pollution controls at its refinery in Woods Cross, Utah, and pay a $120,000 civil penalty to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Dallas-based Holly Refining and Marketing Company (Holly), resolving alleged Clean Air Act violations at the company's refinery in Woods Cross, Utah. The company has agreed to pay civil penalties of $115,000 for violations of risk management program requirements associated with the storage and use of flammable substances and hazardous chemicals.

The Department of Justice and the Environment Protection Agency announced a settlement with HollyFrontier Corporation subsidiaries that resolved alleged Clean Air Act violations regarding fuel quality emissions standards and testing requirements at three HollyFrontier facilities.
back pay award in unfair labor practices case

Company: Navajo Refining Company and Montana Refining Company
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, the companies, then subsidiaries of Holly Corp., agreed to spend up to $21 million to reduce emissions, pay a $750,000 civil penalty and spend $1.5 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company, a subsidiary of major oil and gasoline producer Sinclair Oil, was sentenced to pay a criminal penalty of $5 million and a community service payment of $500,000 for environmental violations at the Tulsa Refinery.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Frontier Refining and Frontier El Dorado Refining
Description: Frontier agreed to pay $1.38 million in penalties to Wyoming, Kansas and the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations at three refineries. This was part of a larger $142 million settlement announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/wyoming-kansas-refiners-agree-settle-clean-air-act-violations

Company: Navajo Refining Company and Montana Refining Company
Description: Navajo Refining Company and Montana Refining Company agreed to pay $750,000 to Montana and New Mexico as well as the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. This was part of a larger $23 million settlement announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-navajo-refining-company-and-montana-refi

EPA and the state of Kansas announced a settlement with HollyFrontier El Dorado Refining LLC to address alleged Clean Air Act violations resulting from exceedances of emission limits and failure to comply with chemical accident prevention statutory and regulatory safety requirements at its El Dorado, Kansas refinery. Under the terms of the agreement, HollyFrontier agreed to pay a $4 million civil penalty and make improvements to the refinery that will greatly reduce harmful air emissions of sulfur dioxide and particulate matter; two pollutants which can cause serious respiratory problems, as well as improve its risk management practices.
